content.title: Juxtarenal Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm
content.description: An abdominal aortic aneurysm that extends to involve the aorta immediately below the renal arteries, leaving insufficient infrarenal neck for standard endovascular repair.
content.definition: Juxtarenal AAA is defined as an aneurysm where the proximal extent reaches the level of the renal arteries but does not involve them, with less than 10-15mm of infrarenal aortic neck. This anatomic pattern presents unique challenges for both open and endovascular repair due to the need for suprarenal clamping or specialized endografts.

key_anatomic_criteria: Renal arteries not incorporated in aneurysm
May have angulated or conical neck
treatment_considerations: Suprarenal aortic clamping required for open repair
Fenestrated or branched EVAR as endovascular option
Higher risk of renal ischemic injury
outcomes: Increased operative mortality vs infrarenal repair
Long-term survival comparable if survived surgery

learning_objectives: Define juxtarenal AAA by anatomic criteria
Understand treatment implications of short infrarenal neck
clinical_pearls: The 'hostile neck' includes short length (<15mm), angulation >60Â°, thrombus >2mm, and conical shape
Suprarenal clamp time >30 minutes increases renal dysfunction risk
Fenestrated EVAR allows treatment with preserved renal perfusion
Cold crystalloid renal perfusion can extend safe clamp time
